1. For the future infinitive he keeps near to the ancient indeclinable form to this extent that he never adds esse. Cicero inserts and omits esse with equal readiness,

2. He extends to the nominative case (which Cicero does not do) the use of a participle and noun in agreement equiva- lent practically in sense to an abstract noun : e. g. 13 ξ 8.

3. Etiam in Livy sometimes precedes, sometimes follows what it emphasizes. In Cicero it seems always to precede.

4. His syntax in oratio obliqua does not entirely conform to the rules deduced by grammarians from Ciceronian usage: e·g·1§4‚2§5‚6§13-
